Award.AwardTitle: Doctoral Dissertation Research: Livelihood Strategies and Landscape Diversity Related to Agricultural Development

Directorate.LongName: Direct For Social, Behav & Economic Scie

Division.LongName: Division Of Behavioral and Cognitive Sci

Award.AbstractNarration:
Changes in the ways that people construct their livelihoods transform the landscape, and landscape changes have implications for livelihoods. The often complex relationships between people and the natural landscapes they inhabit are the focus of scientific research designed to enhance more general knowledge, but such research can have practical implications for decision making about development endeavors. This doctoral dissertation research project will examine how agricultural development programs are transforming livelihood diversity and landscape pattern in rural communities. Understanding interactions among changes in landscape and livelihoods of rural populations is particularly important in those locales where development programs and investors have turned their attention to agricultural growth in this area. In this context, information about the broader effects of agricultural growth can inform development agencies as they seek to balance the tradeoffs among food production, poverty alleviation, and environmental conservation. This is the case in the Morogoro Region in Tanzania, where this project will take place, because interactions in this region have posed challenges for the ongoing efforts of the U.S. Agency for International Development's Feed the Future program and for the Tanzanian government's Kilimo Kwanza [Agriculture First] strategy. This project will contribute to these development efforts by gathering information about the economic activities and needs of rural populations and by performing empirical analysis of environmental data. Through close work with rural populations and groups engaged in development activities, the doctoral student will identify new opportunities for enhancing the resilience of rural communities in Tanzania and in many other developing nations. As a Doctoral Dissertation Research Improvement award, this award also will provide support to enable a promising student to establish a strong independent research career.

While extensive research has been dedicated to examining livelihoods and land use, little research has specifically addressed this reciprocal relationship between space and livelihoods. Recent research has suggested that space is central to livelihoods analyses and is essential to understanding the processes that give rise to rural livelihood strategies. The doctoral student whose dissertation research will be supported by this award will examine an area where extensive agricultural change spurred by development initiatives and foreign investment is underway. He will integrate research methods from landscape ecology, land-change science, and sustainable livelihoods research to examine the changes in spatial patterns of landscapes over the past two decades as well as the changes in livelihood strategies related to these development activities. Using satellite imagery, he will identify changes in the spatial pattern of land use and land cover over time. He will conduct interviews and gather survey data from smallholder famers to complement this analysis and explain how agricultural programs have altered livelihood strategies and resource use in the area. He also will interview representatives from development agencies and other stakeholder groups to ascertain their perceptions of the changes in the environment and the needs of rural populations. Through this mixed-methods approach, the student will provide new understandings about the complex relationship between changes in livelihood strategies and landscape pattern as well as new insights into how development programs shape this relationship.

The Kilombero Valley of Tanzania is an area of global importance for biodiversity conservation, comprising both wetland and forest habitats that host abundant endemic species. At the same time, this area is undergoing rapid agricultural development as part of both international and domestic programs to improve food security and to reduce poverty. This research project explores the intersection of conservation and development endeavors, and assesses impacts of agricultural development on habitat fragmentation and food security outcomes in the region. Specifically, this work seeks to reveal how development endeavors are reshaping the relationships among livelihoods and land use in the Kilombero Valley, and the implications for meeting both conservation and food security objectives.

 

During 2014, researchers conducted interviews with forty representatives from conservation, development, and community organizations involved with activities in Kilombero District of Tanzania. In addition, 280 households in eight villages were surveyed in order to gather information on livelihood activities, agricultural practices, and use of natural resources. Finally, satellite imagery spanning a nearly 20-year time period was analyzed to characterize changes in land cover and forest fragmentation in Kilombero District.

 

The results reveal dramatic changes in forest cover and agricultural areas over recent decades. Agriculture has expanded rapidly, primarily at the expense of forest and wetlands in the Kilombero Valley. The rates of deforestation are most rapid in close proximity to the sites of current agricultural development programs associated with foreign investment in rice production near the village of Mngeta. Deforestation rates are slowest in the Northeastern portion of the Valley, where international coordination has successfully implemented forest conservation programs. Focus group meetings, however, reveal that conservation efforts are also constraining farming opportunities and causing the displacement of practices to other areas in the Valley.

 

The challenges in balancing these agricultural and conservation endeavors were reflected in interviews among various stakeholders. Nonetheless, further analysis (Q-analysis) of interview responses reveals that there is a great deal of overlap in the perceptions of environmental and development challenges in the Valley. The results demonstrate a growing involvement of conservation organizations in livelihoods activities and the increasing recognition of the importance of conservation for supporting water resources for agriculture. Differences, however, persist in views regarding the importance of agricultural and livelihood diversification for reducing demand on land and natural resources.

 

Household surveys indicate that the benefits from agricultural diversity are also geographically dependent, influenced by access to land and other resources. In general, there was not a clear relationship between crop diversification and food security, though it appears to support greater dietary diversity. Households involved in off-farm income-generating activities, however, did generally indicate greater food security.

 

This research provides insights into the patterns and impacts of agricultural development on social and environmental outcomes in this important region. POR.POR_COPY_TXT: The Kilombero Valley of Tanzania is an area of global importance for biodiversity conservation, comprising both wetland and forest habitats that host abundant endemic species. In addition, 280 households in eight villages were surveyed in order to gather information on livelihood activities, agricultural practices, and use of natural resources. The results reveal dramatic changes in forest cover and agricultural areas over recent decades. Agriculture has expanded rapidly, primarily at the expense of forest and wetlands in the Kilombero Valley. The rates of deforestation are most rapid in close proximity to the sites of current agricultural development programs associated with foreign investment in rice production near the village of Mngeta. Deforestation rates are slowest in the Northeastern portion of the Valley, where international coordination has successfully implemented forest conservation programs. The challenges in balancing these agricultural and conservation endeavors were reflected in interviews among various stakeholders. Nonetheless, further analysis (Q-analysis) of interview responses reveals that there is a great deal of overlap in the perceptions of environmental and development challenges in the Valley. The results demonstrate a growing involvement of conservation organizations in livelihoods activities and the increasing recognition of the importance of conservation for supporting water resources for agriculture. Differences, however, persist in views regarding the importance of agricultural and livelihood diversification for reducing demand on land and natural resources. Household surveys indicate that the benefits from agricultural diversity are also geographically dependent, influenced by access to land and other resources. In general, there was not a clear relationship between crop diversification and food security, though it appears to support greater dietary diversity. Households involved in off-farm income-generating activities, however, did generally indicate greater food security. This research provides insights into the patterns and impacts of agricultural development on social and environmental outcomes in this important region. Furthermore, it reveals both opportunities and challenges to advancing current agricultural development programs. The mixed methods approach provides a framework to evaluate the tradeoffs inherent in agricultural development and to assess the differentiated impacts of these tradeoffs in other regions while also contributing to baseline knowledge on the relationship between food security and agricultural diversity. These findings can immediately support ongoing development activities in the Kilombero Valley and elsewhere in East Africa. Last Modified: 04/08/2016 Submitted by: John Connors
